1091337947578880006.text: As a final touch, I set the default function to pay all amounts due and be public, so it allows a service like ethereum alarm clock to schedule a call for a given day of the month. We recently tested today and it all worked like a charm. Here's the code:https://github.com/alexvandesande/payroll/blob/master/contract.sol …

1091337946043686912.text: At first I considered using Aragon's "Payroll" app, which inspired the idea of setting a yearly salary and allow you to be paid per block. But that app is under development and the buffer dai would stay locked on the contract, not generating interest. So I decided to build my own

1091337944424681472.text: Since it required a 3 step process for paying (submit, approve, execute), it would meant to pay 4 people I would need to sign 12 transactions or more (I also had to manually add the day rate).  The move to DAI could help most of these points.

1091337943229304834.text: But mostly it became just a way to make sure everyone got paid on time, while it reduced the overhead from HR people that now only had to make one transaction to pay many invoices, since everyone asked to the same address. But it did increase my overhead as I now had to manage it

1091337941610311680.text: The buffer would pay them immediately on the latest exchange rate and then at some point it would be paid back at whatever exchange it was sent to. It had other functions too, requiring secondary approval, listing individual invoices, even a place to put swarm files.

1091337940268130307.text: In highly volatile months you could receive 30% more or 50% less than you expected. While it can lead to some good surprises, people don't like to gamble their salary usually. So I proposed a solution for my own team: they would invoice to a buffer contract.

1091337939035009025.text: The result is that for a long time the decision was that the exchange rate used would always be either the 1st or 15th of the invoiced month, depending on when the invoice arrived. It simplified things for one side, but also created an inconvenience for those being paid.

1091337937718075392.text: Also, payments in ether are complicated for accounting due to volatility. Do you use the exchange rate of the invoice or the day the tx is sent? People send invoices in different days, it takes some time for the person responsible to go through payments, it's not trivial.

1091337936115777536.text: First of all, it's actually quite hard – purposefully – to move funds. Some of the bigger wallets the foundation has have been an original multisig code, which is safe but only works with command line tools. At some point we had to wait for busy people like Vitalik to sign a tx.

There should also be a correlation between being pro-life, against euthanasia, and believing it would be unethical to create an hypothetical lab-grown headless human body for organ transplant. 
It’s a testable hypothesis.

1068837282365534208.text: Because models that don’t make new predictions aren’t useful I’ll make one: if this hypothesis is correct, there should be a correlation between being vegetarian, pro-choice and believing that it’s unethical to delete an hypothetical conscious AI.

1068837280255741952.text: It’s like someone trying to tell someone that is a fan of fast cars that a given car is better by showing them how fuel efficient it is. They’re completely different measures and you can’t have an intelligent discussion without acknowledging that first.

1068837278129287170.text: Conversely, there’s no doubt that a human Blastula is both human and alive but obviously no more conscious than a fungus. That’s why someone with the “humanness” position is unable to understand or empathize with someone from the “consciousness” argument.

1068837276350861312.text: It also shows why some arguments falls in deaf ears: saying “a 4 week old fetus is just a bunch of cells” or “pigs are highly intelligent” is about consciousness, so it’s ineffective for a “humanness” defender.

1068837274182402049.text: It’s interesting because both sides have a valid scientific view, because the only answer from science to “when life begins” is “about 4 billion years ago” (excluding panspermia theories). Defining which sort of life needs protection is purely a moral definition.

1068837272198545408.text: The other side measures life in terms of “humanness”: this is usually the position of a “life begins at conception” pro-lifer, defender of the meat industry (even if seen as a necessary evil). If it’s human and alive, doesn’t matter how small, it has rights above all others.

1068837270424301568.text: One side measures life in terms of consciousness: this is usually the position of a pro-choice (until the neural tube forms), for strong animal rights and for euthanasia of people who are brain dead. If something has the ability to think and suffer, it needs protective rights.

1068837267651874816.text: I have a curious theory on why most people have a hard time even understanding the other side on the controversial topics of abortion, euthanasia and veganism: each side is using a completely different measure for what sort of life that needs protection, but don’t realize it.

1) one vote per person, one candidate per party per district

3) votes over quota are transferred to most voted candidate in same party in same city, then state, then national
4) repeat until no vote is wasted

I’m all for everyone to have freedom. But people without choices (or knowledge) are never free. Poverty often leaves very little choices.

Otherwise all we’ll be doing is giving more freedom for those who are already rich.

1058707695904141312.text:
I hope Spankchain succeeds at their goal of giving more freedom to sex workers.

But if we want a positive impact in the world, we also need more apps to tackle the missing piece of getting poor young woman access to sources of revenue other than sex work.

1058707693895065602.text: I think a lot of supporters of sex industry come from men who want the service to be more available, not from the point of view of empowering and helping those who provide it. Ameen is the bro-character, they would do good in letting Chelsea represent them more.

1058707691944796161.text: Ameen, the CEO, stumbled and questioned her numbers (source? I gave a TED talk. In a poor country? Canada). Chelsea answered that by giving control of their own finances and reducing the stigma of former sex workers, they were helping give everyone a better way out.

1058707689969192961.text: And interesting moment was that after the Spankchain talk a woman in the audience questioned that was all very good for the women who had the privilege of choice in the matter but what they were doing to help the 50%+ sex workers who are victims of sex trafficking?

1058707687674908672.text: She talked about the large intersection in crypto and sex industry as both strive for autonomy, the importance of privacy and creating a system in which you can’t be forced to have your (money/body) taken away and used without your consent

1058707678699184129.text: When I first heard about @SpankChain I’ve dismissed as “whatever, porn’s an early adopter and they want to jump the ICO bandwagon”. Then they started shipping production state channels and working apps and I found it a funny curiosity. But Chelsea makes it about something bigger.

1058707676899749888.text: She does a very good job at trying to be out there reducing stigma about women in the sex industry (she’s part of the Spankchain team) to be seen not as body parts for sale, but autonomous humans with many dimensions that just happen to work in a controversial service industry

1043119644943499264.text: My point being: trying to shoehorn crypto in the traditional definition of money as invented by an English economist in 1875 is obviously futile. Our goal is trying to replicate all the current economic system running in your personal pocket computer. And then reinvent it.

1043119643416829953.text: Unit of account: that's just a measurement, you can measure how much your fund is in dollars, even if it has no dollars in it. I predict most people will measure it in traditional fiat (USD/EUR/GBP..) but eventually someone will create the SI equivalent of money.

1043119641562886144.text: Store of value: once you receive the money, you instantly convert it into your preferred store of value. Probably not any single coin, but a large and diverse portfolio of financial instruments that grows your value slowly over time. Your own personal hedge fund built in crypto.

1043119639893553152.text: Medium of exchange (this is where I believe bitcoin can really share – or any other crypto that fixes scalability better): that's just a internet money protocol. I want to send value to you and we connect to the system. You only care about volatility during the transmission time.

1043119638203297793.text: There’s a common thread in crypto that in order to be successful as money bitcoin will inevitably have to be a unit of account, a store of value and a medium of exchange. I disagree and think we’d be served better by breaking those up in separate parts. For example:

1008501165154283520.text: Were these lessons valuable? Definitely. Could we have learned them by other ways? Probably. Was the stress, the distractions, the change in culture, the community split worth the cost of learning them? I don’t think so anymore.

1008501163040354309.text: A fork has been proven as a valid Exit option for disenfranchised community members that feel they have no voice. But I don’t believe fork as governance is something to be cheered and seen as a reason not to work on tools that empower and give voice to your own community

1008501161115217920.text: But also, we learned that blockchains are replaceable by a community on top of it. Code is law, but we can always turn off the machines and decide to work on new code and a new law and that new code can become more valuable. Value is just faith.

1008501159018065921.text: Most importantly, we learned how resilient blockchains are. Ethereum Classic is what happens when original developers and a whole community decide to leave an old chain to die in the side of the road. Instead it survived and came back with a vengeance. It’s inspiring really.

1008501156908273664.text: But we have indeed learned a lot about forks. Before it, forking an existing blockchain was a theoretical possibility that most people believed would threaten the original chain on a “there can only be one” combat. I wonder if Bitcoin Cash/Gold would have happened.

1008501153754206209.text: I’m also confident looking back that even if it had not the reentrancy bug or governance problems, the DAO was doomed. Think about the ICO craze that came later, but one in which people could vote (and buy votes!) to invest in them with other people’s money. Not good.

1008501151669673984.text: The values back then felt gigantic and community-threatening. I don’t think they were. I remember a common recommendation post hack never to store more than a million dollars in a single smart contract. Those figures are laughable now.

1008501149580824576.text: Also a Fork was sold as the “clean” option, the one that would solve the problem quickly so that everyone could get back to work. Instead the fork created arguments that persist to this day. While ETH/ETC communities have been mostly at peace, that animosity is still brought up.

1008501147064262656.text:
Firstly, the White Hat hackers have shown to be extremely competent and I feel confident they would have been able to rescue at least 70%-90% of the funds back to dao token holders (as they did).

They knew it was a possibility then, but they didn’t want that pressure on them.

1008501144887463937.text: Knowing everything I know today, I don’t think the hard fork was worth its many downsides. But I wouldn’t know most of that if not for the fork.https://twitter.com/el33th4xor/status/1008417777663774720 …

990400908591861760.text:
7) embrace bots 

AI is your friend not the enemy. Allow players to build bots, allow bots to be players under the same rules. Maybe coding bots and freeing them on the world might be the most fun

990400904879800321.text:
6) allow others to design 

You don’t need to design everything, if you make a great platform others can expand it. Allow them to create new monsters or levels, leave room for someone to update the graphics or make a new expansion.

990400901159497728.text:
5) players own the game 

Don’t make a game just so that the users buy stuff from you. Make it so that users own many aspects of the game. They own the land, they own the equipment they own the experience. At some point they should have as much or more control than you.

990400897384632320.text:
4) persistent worlds 

Your game doesn’t have multiple servers and will still exist even after you stop developing it. Explore that. Make that communities live and grow on it

990400891508477953.text:
3) design around the limitations 

Only have few moves per second? Then make it strategic turns. Can’t have secret information? Make a commit reveal scheme as part of the game. Moves are expensive? Figure out what actually needs consensus. Need unexplored regions? PoW maps.
